Joint Probability (2/2)
▪ Hence, in a Bayesian network, P(X) = P(X1, X2, …, Xd) can be 
represented as
P(X) = P(X1, X2, …, Xd)
= P(X1)P(X2|X1) P(X3|X1, X2)…P(Xd |X1, …, Xd-1)
= P(X1|parents(X1))P(X2|parents(X2))…P(Xd |parents(Xd))
▪ In other words, it is sufficient to consider only parents(Xi) for 
computing P(Xi |X1, …, Xi-1)
▪ The value of each P(Xi|parents(Xi)) can be obtained using 
probability tables, which will be described in the next slide
